Workspace¶

class mrscfastcom.workspace.Workspace¶

A class with a Graph instance, grid length and vertices and coordinates one-to-one mapping.

Variables

  • graph – A Graph instance.

  • grid_length – The length of the grids in the workspace. Assume all the grids are square.

__getitem__()¶

This operator received Vertex, Vector2d, or 2d-tuple instance as input. If a vertex is provided, then return the coordinate of the vertex (if the mapping exists). If a Vector2d or 2d-tuple instance is provided, then return the instance that is mapped to the coordinate. The 2d-tuple will be automatic converted to Vector2d with the corresponding coordinate. KeyError will be raised if there have no mapping from the given input.

Parameters

c (Vector2d) – Target coordinate.

Returns

The vertex mapped to the given coordinate.

Return type

Vertex

Raises

KeyError – Item doesn’t exist.

Example

>>> from mrscfastcom.workspace import *
>>> w = Workspace(75, 75, 0.6)

>>> w[Vector2d(0, 0)]
<Vertex: 0>

>>> w[(0, 0)] == w[Vector2d(0, 0)]
True

>>> w[Vertex(0)]
<Vector2d: 0.000000, 0.000000>

>>> try:
...     w[Vertex(-1)]
... except KeyError:
...     print("KeyError")
KeyError
__init__()¶

There have two constructors: non-arg or \((n, m, l)\). \(n \times m\) is the number of grids in the workspace and \(l\) is the length of the grids. Note that all grids are square in shape. For the second constructor, all the vertices, edges, and mapping will be created.

Parameters

  • n (int) – The number of grids in row.

  • m (int) – The number of grids in col.

  • l (double) – The length of grids.

Return type

None

Example

>>> from mrscfastcom.workspace import *
>>> w = Workspace(75, 75, 0.6)
>>> len(w.graph.vertices)
5625
>>> len(w.graph.edges)
22200
get_cord()¶

Get coordinate that map to the given vertex. Equivalent with w[v] where w is the instance of Workspace.

Parameters

v (Vertex) – Target vertex.

Returns

The coordinate mapped to the given vertex.

Return type

Vector2d

Raises

KeyError – Item doesn’t exist.

get_inv_cord()¶

Get vertex that map to the given coordinate. Equivalent with w[c] where w is the instance of Workspace.

Parameters

c (Vector2d) – Target coordinate.

Returns

The vertex mapped to the given coordinate.

Return type

Vertex

Raises

KeyError – Item doesn’t exist.

set_mapping()¶

Set the one-to-one mapping between a coordinate and a vertex. Equivalent with w[v] = c or w[c] = v where w is the instance of Workspace.

Parameters

  • v (Vertex) – Target vertex.

  • c (Vector2d) – Target coordinate.

Return type

None

Example

>>> w = Workspace()
>>> w.set_mapping(Vertex(1), Vector2d(10, 10))
>>> w[Vertex(1)]
<Vector2d: 10.000000, 10.000000>

>>> w[Vertex(2)] = Vector2d(10, 12)
>>> w[Vertex(2)]
<Vector2d: 10.000000, 12.000000>

>>> w[w[Vertex(1)]]
<Vertex: 1>

Graph¶

class mrscfastcom.workspace.Graph¶

Directed graph with edges and vertices.

Variables

  • vertices – A readonly-set of vertices.

  • edges – A readonly-set of edges.

exists()¶

This function receives Vertex or Edge as input. Check if a given input in the graph instance.

Parameters

item (Union[Edge, Vertex]) – An instance of Vertex or Edge.

Returns

true if the provided input in the graph instance, false otherwise.

Return type

bool

Example

>>> from mrscfastcom.workspace import *
>>> v1 = Vertex(1)
>>> v2 = Vertex(2)
>>> v3 = Vertex(3)
>>> e = Edge(v1, v2)

>>> g = Graph()
>>> g.insert(v1)
>>> g.exists(v1)
True

>>> g.exists(v2)
False

>>> g.insert(e)
>>> g.exists(e)
True

>>> e2 = Edge(v2, v1)
>>> g.exists(e2)
False
get_dt_predecessors()¶

This function is to get the direct predecessors of the input vertex.

Parameters

v (Union[Edge, Vertex]) – An instance of Vertex.

Returns

A set of predecessors.

Return type

Set[Vertex]

Example

>>> v1 = Vertex(1)
>>> v2 = Vertex(2)
>>> v3 = Vertex(3)
>>> e1 = Edge(v1, v2)
>>> e2 = Edge(v1, v3)
>>> e3 = Edge(v3, v2)

>>> g = Graph()
>>> g.insert(e1)
>>> g.insert(e2)
>>> g.insert(e3)

>>> g.get_dt_predecessors(v1)
set()

>>> {v1, v3} == g.get_dt_predecessors(v2)
True

>>> g.get_dt_predecessors(v3)
{<Vertex: 1>}
get_dt_successors()¶

This function is to get the direct successors of the input vertex.

Parameters

v (Union[Edge, Vertex]) – An instance of Vertex.

Returns

A set of successors.

Return type

Set[Vertex]

Example

>>> v1 = Vertex(1)
>>> v2 = Vertex(2)
>>> v3 = Vertex(3)
>>> e1 = Edge(v1, v2)
>>> e2 = Edge(v1, v3)
>>> e3 = Edge(v3, v2)

>>> g = Graph()
>>> g.insert(e1)
>>> g.insert(e2)
>>> g.insert(e3)

>>> {v2, v3} == g.get_dt_successors(v1)
True

>>> g.get_dt_successors(v2)
set()

>>> g.get_dt_successors(v3)
{<Vertex: 2>}
insert()¶

This function receives Vertex or Edge as input. The provided input will be added to the corresponding set.

Parameters

item (Union[Edge, Vertex]) – An instance of Vertex or Edge.

Example

>>> v1 = Vertex(1)
>>> v2 = Vertex(2)
>>> v3 = Vertex(3)
>>> e = Edge(v1, v2)

>>> g = Graph()
>>> g.insert(v3)
>>> g.vertices
{<Vertex: 3>}

>>> g.insert(e)
>>> v1 in g.vertices and v2 in g.vertices and v3 in g.vertices
True

>>> g.edges
{<Edge: 1, 2>}
remove()¶

This function receives Vertex or Edge as input. The provided input will be removed from the corresponding set. Please note that removing a vertex will also remove the edges containing the vertex. However, removing an edge does not delete the vertices of the edge.

Parameters

item (Union[Edge, Vertex]) – An instance of Vertex or Edge.

Example

>>> v1 = Vertex(1)
>>> v2 = Vertex(2)
>>> v3 = Vertex(3)
>>> e = Edge(v1, v2)

>>> g = Graph()
>>> g.insert(v3)
>>> g.insert(e)
>>> v1 in g.vertices and v2 in g.vertices and v3 in g.vertices and e in g.edges
True

>>> g.remove(e)
>>> e not in g.edges and e.endPointX in g.vertices and e.endPointY in g.vertices 
True

>>> g.remove(v3)
>>> v3 in g.vertices
False

>>> g.edges
set()

Vertex¶

class mrscfastcom.workspace.Vertex¶

This a class to generate vertices with immutable unique identifiers (id).

Variables

id – The unique identifier of instance. Vertices with same id are considered identical.

__eq__()¶

Two vertices are considered identical if they both have the same id.

Example

>>> from mrscfastcom.workspace import *
>>> v1 = Vertex(1)
>>> v2 = Vertex(v1.id)
>>> v1 == v2
True

>>> v3 = Vertex(2)
>>> v1 == v3
False
__init__()¶

Constructor of vertex. The id of any vertex should be a nonnegative int.

Parameters

id (unsigned int) – The custom unique identifier of the vertex.

Example

>>> Vertex(1)
<Vertex: 1>

Edge¶

class mrscfastcom.workspace.Edge¶

A class with two vertices (endPointX and endPointY). This is to represent directed edge.

Variables

  • endPointX – First endpoint.

  • endPointY – Second endpoint.

__eq__()¶

Two edges e1, e2 are same if e1.endPointX == e2.endPointX and e1.endPointY == e2.endPointY.

Example

>>> from mrscfastcom.workspace import *
>>> v1 = Vertex(1)
>>> v2 = Vertex(2)
>>> e1 = Edge(v1, v2)
>>> e2 = Edge(v2, v1)
>>> e1 == e2
False

>>> e1 == Edge(v1, v2)
True
__init__()¶

Constructor of Edge with two parameters.

Parameters

  • v1 (Vertex) – endPointX.

  • v2 (Vertex) – endPointY.

Example

>>> from mrscfastcom.workspace import *
>>> v1 = Vertex(1)
>>> v2 = Vertex(2)
>>> Edge(v1, v2)
<Edge: 1, 2>

Vector2d¶

class mrscfastcom.workspace.Vector2d¶

This is a class with two numerical attributes. Its instances have similar properties as mathematical 2d vectors.

Variables

  • x – x-value.

  • y – y-value.

__add__()¶

Add two vectors and returns the result.

Example

>>> from mrscfastcom.workspace import Vector2d
>>> Vector2d(1, 2) + Vector2d(5, 3)
<Vector2d: 6.000000, 5.000000>
__eq__()¶

Compare two vectors.

Example

>>> Vector2d(1, 2) == Vector2d(5, 3)
False

>>> Vector2d(1, 2) != Vector2d(5, 3)
True

>>> Vector2d(1, 2) == Vector2d(1, 2)
True
__iadd__()¶

Add two vectors and updates the value of lhs-vector.

Example

>>> v1 = Vector2d(1, 2)
>>> v1 += Vector2d(5, 3)
>>> v1
<Vector2d: 6.000000, 5.000000>
__init__()¶

Constructor.

Parameters

  • x (double) – x-value.

  • y (double) – y-value.

Example

>>> Vector2d(2, 0)
<Vector2d: 2.000000, 0.000000>
__isub__()¶

lhs-vector subtracts rhs-vector and updates the value of lhs-vector.

Example

>>> v1 = Vector2d(1, 2)
>>> v1 -= Vector2d(5, 3)
>>> v1
<Vector2d: -4.000000, -1.000000>
__lshift__()¶

Equivalent to lhs-vector subtracts rhs-vector (lhs - rhs).

Example

>>> v1 = Vector2d(1, 2)
>>> v2 = Vector2d(2, 0)
>>> v1 << v2
<Vector2d: -1.000000, 2.000000>
__rshift__()¶

Equivalent to rhs-vector subtracts lhs-vector (rhs - lhs).

Example

>>> v1 = Vector2d(1, 2)
>>> v2 = Vector2d(2, 0)
>>> v1 >> v2
<Vector2d: 1.000000, -2.000000>
__sub__()¶

lhs-vector subtracts rhs-vector and returns the result.

Example

>>> Vector2d(1, 2) - Vector2d(5, 3)
<Vector2d: -4.000000, -1.000000>
get_angle_df()¶

Calculate and return the angle difference between two vectors (in radian).

\[\theta = cos^{-1} \frac{v_1 \cdot v_2}{|v_1||v_2|}\]
Parameters

v (Vector2d) – target vector.

Return type

double

Example

>>> Vector2d(1, 0).get_angle_df(Vector2d(2, 0))
0.0

>>> Vector2d(1, 0).get_angle_df(Vector2d(-1, 0))
3.141592653589793

>>> Vector2d(1, 0).get_angle_df(Vector2d(0, 1))
1.5707963267948966

>>> Vector2d(1, 0).get_angle_df(Vector2d(0, -1))
1.5707963267948966

>>> Vector2d(1, 0).get_angle_df(Vector2d(1.123, 2.324))
1.120663750004051
get_unit_vector()¶

Calculate and return the unit vector of the caller.

Return type

Vector2d

Example

>>> Vector2d(2, 0).get_unit_vector()
<Vector2d: 1.000000, 0.000000>
